title: Fioras new Passive AND ult deal %MaxHP True Damage
body:
"Duelist's Dance (Passive)

Fiora identifies Vitals on nearby enemy champions. Fiora will reveal a new Vital afte striking the last one, or after 15 seconds.
When Fiora strikes a Vital, she deals 3 (+X)% of the target's maximum health in true damage,[...]

Grand Challenge (R)

Fiora reveals all four Vitals on the target champion, each dealing 12 (+X)% of the target's maximum health in true damage, [...]

We believe that though %HP true damage can cause frustration, there _is_ a time and place for that mechanic, and there are two primary reasons why we decided to go with it in this case:

First, we want Fiora to win and loses fights by skill, not stats. Accordingly, no one can mitigate her passive damage, but anyone can avoid it entirely through skillful play. When Fiora loses, it's because her opponent outplayed her through clever footwork and proper use of their CC's or re-positioning abilities.

Second, the Grand Duelist takes on all opponents, and %HP true damage allows her to threaten bulkier ones without having an unfair advantage against the more fragile. If it dealt %HP physical damage instead, the number would have to be _much_ larger to scratch through a tank's armor, and that same number would mean instant death to unarmored opponents.

Though it may seem like the opposite, the mechanic actually protects many targets from the more dangerous alternatives -- and though there are no macro countermeasures (like building armor), there is theoretically rich micro counterplay (don't let her hit it). So while this still may cause some frustration, I hope this at least explains why it's on the kit!

> there is theoretically rich micro counterplay (don't let her hit it)

What if you're Garen? Literally can't do anything to stop her from hitting your weak spot aside from running away or outright killing her, but Fiora's Q and speed boost will help her keep pace. What micro counterplay can we employ if we assume our champion does not have dashes or blinks?

Yeah, it's not equally rich across all champions. Fortunately, champions without high mobility spells or immobilizing cc's often have the damage to beat Fiora if she tries to straight up fight them, Garen included. If Fiora is spending time moving between Vitals while fighting Garen in melee range, I expect that his basic combo should be sufficiently punishing to her.

This is not a catch-all answer, but most champions have some action they can take against Fiora, whether through dodging, stunning, or dumping damage when she exposes herself to risk. She will have particularly favorable matchups against certain champions, but that's a part of champion-to-champion interaction in League. Of course, it becomes a problem when Fiora has VERY binary matchups, and to your point, this is something we'll be on the lookout for.

Basically: When Garen recognizes that Fiora is going to come in for an open Vital, he can ready his Q/E to punish her.

Fiora's Q range and passive haste might be strong enough such that they invalidate this play, but that's not the intention, and we can tune these things down to compensate.

This kind of justification makes me... uncomfortable. I've seen it more places than just here too. It seems that we are leaning towards the outcome of a fight being decided more and more by what happens in the actual ten seconds or so of engagement rather than the positioning and resource expenditure of the previous thirty seconds, or the items bought five minutes ago. Justifications like "counterplay" are used to rationalize more power in kits and less on items, or skillshots rather than targeted damage. Resources have become less important with many manaless champions seeing play, and even mana users tend to forget about the resource after an item or two.

The problem here is that tactics is being emphasized more than strategy. MOBAs as a genre appeal differently than say FPS games in that you have persistent power that can dramatically change over the course of a game. One or more players can "carry" the team to victory, and both the successes and failures revolving around carries make the game more interesting. If that's gone, it's easy to feel powerless to make up for a struggling team. Shut-down gold, for instance, becomes less meaningful when items like armor are less powerful.

When we emphasize tactics, twitch reflex and teamwork become more important than individual performance and anticipation. It's like we've forgotten that it's both frustrating and fun to win or lose by fighting or becoming the player that carries the game. It's like we've forgotten that buying a Banshee's Veil to block that Annie nuke is arguably purer counterplay than *sidestepping* a Veigar's Baleful Strike. By allowing counterplay in anticipation the game becomes more cerebral. Encounters aren't won or lost by a tenth of a second swing.

As it is, it feels like the game is leaning towards something that might be very tense and entertaining to watch, but is not that much fun to play. League was fun because it *wasn't* like a twitch shooter. That's less true now. "Skill, not stats," is a worrisome philosophy when stats tend to be determined by things that absolutely *should* matter, such as anticipatory counterplay (buying items) and past performance (how well you've performed so far in a given game).

And come to think of it, aren't squishy champions *supposed* to take more damage? If there's a problem where a skill *has to* either deal too much damage to squishies or too little to tanks, shouldn't we be looking at the balance between squishies and tanks rather than trying to cook questionable damage calculations into skills like this?

> "Skill, not stats," is a worrisome philosophy when stats tend to be determined by things that absolutely should matter, such as anticipatory counterplay (buying items) and past performance (how well you've performed so far in a given game).

The issue with this is that it's actually stronger against tanks than against squishy targets, especially with Riposte.  Tanks generally have cc (but that can now be parried).  Essentially, by building more damage an ADC stands a better chance against Fiora, but a tank shouldn't build more damage -  they have no way to prevent her from killing them just as fast.  With 75% armour pen physical damage, it would at least allow the tank to defend a little bit against her.

Vayne has the same problem - the only response a tank can have to her is Randuins/Frozen Heart.  Against a heavy AP team, that means that the tank has to build one of two items that only help against a single champion on the enemy team.  Yes, Frozen Heart helps against Azir and Randuins helps with its slow.  Any other champion can build damage and hope to burst her down, but a tank literally has no other recourse.

Percent max health true damage disproportionately punishes tanks.  This is not an issue with Vayne (Well, I still think it is, but I main Leona) as she is supposed to bust tanks.  On the other hand, the goal is Fiora is to make her capable of fighting anyone with relatively equal ease.  In order to do this, it would actually be better to give her 75% (or so) armour pen on her Vital Strikes, so that tanks are capable of fighting her but still have items available to buy which they can build to help fight her.

A BRUISER can, an ADC can (provided they manage to survive Fiora's basic attacks of course,) But a tank... Can just kinda sit there and take it. There are, obviously, exceptions to this like say, Sejuani whom is based around consistent damage, Amumu with his constant damage and MR Shred and Volibear with his health-scaling execute. 

A tank will have to do one of three things; 
1. Wait Fiora's damage out until an ally can come save them,
2. Run away with their tail between their legs or,
3. Attempt to fight Fiora and lose to the lifesteal Fiora is inevitably going to build, even if she doesn't get to hit the vitals even once. The passive is just insult to injury in this case, really.

I'll be perfectly honest though. Even as someone who used to main tanks (and still plays lots of them,) I'm looking forwards to Fiora's update! It looks like a very fun kit to play with!
